tip.body: * # g* g# each searches for the word under the cursor (forwards/backwards) http://is.gd/7Onk
% matches opening and closing chars (){}[], and with matchit.vim, def/end, HTML tags, etc. as well!  http://is.gd/N4W
< CTRL-n >< CTRL-p > offers word-completion while in insert mode.  http://is.gd/7Onk
< CTRL-x >< CTRL-l > offers line completion in insert mode.  http://is.gd/7Onk
/< CTRL-r >< CTRL-w > will pull the word under the cursor into search.   http://is.gd/7Onk
:h slash< CTRL-d > to get a list of all help topics containing the word 'slash'.  http://is.gd/7Onk
guu converts entire line to lowercase. gUU converts entire line to uppercase.  ~ inverts case of current character.  http://is.gd/7Onk
'. jumps to last modified line.  `. jumps to exact position of last modification.  http://is.gd/7Onk
< CTRL-o > : trace your movements backwards in a file.  < CTRL-i > trace your movements forwards in a file.  http://is.gd/7Onk
:ju(mps) : list your movements {{help|jump-motions}}  http://is.gd/7Onk\
:history lists the history of your recent commands, sans duplicates.   http://is.gd/7Onk
:%s/\ r//g to remove all those nasty ^M from a file, or :%s/\ r$//g for only at the end of a line.  http://is.gd/8ejs
/\%>80v.\+ with search highlighting (:set hlsearch) will highlight any text after column 80.  http://is.gd/8ekT
:match ErrorMsg '\%>80v.\+' uses matching to highlight lines longer than 80 columns.  http://is.gd/8ekT
:vimgrep pattern *.txt will search all .txt files in the current directory for the pattern.  http://is.gd/8epA
:vimgrep pattern **/*.txt will search all *.txt files in the current directory and its subdirectories for the pattern.  http://is.gd/8epA
== will auto-indent the current line.  Select text in visual mode, then = to auto-indent the selected lines. http://is.gd/8etC
Count the number of occurences of a word in a file with :%s/<word>//gn
:set foldmethod=syntax to make editing long files of code much easier.  zo to open a fold.  zc to close it.  See more http://is.gd/9clX
Need to edit and run a previous command?  q: then find the command, edit it, and Enter to execute the line.  http://is.gd/9cuP
@: to repeat the last executed command.  http://is.gd/9cuP
:e $MYVIMRC to directly edit your vimrc.  :source $MYVIMRC to reload.  Mappings may make it even easier. http://is.gd/7Onk
g< CTRL-G > to see technical information about the file, such as how many words are in it, or how many bytes it is.  http://is.gd/9cYj
gq{movement} to wrap text, or just gq while in visual mode. gqap will format the current paragraph.  http://is.gd/7Onk
:E to see a simple file explorer.  (:Ex will too, if that's easier to remember.) http://is.gd/7Onk
"+y to copy to the X11 (or Windows) clipboard.  "+p to paste from it.  http://is.gd/9dkI
noremap ' ` and noremap ` ' to make marks easier to navigate.  Now ` is easier to reach!  http://is.gd/70Dh
In gvim, change the cursor depending on what mode you are in (normal, insert, etc): http://is.gd/9dq0
From a command-line, vim scp://username@host//path/to/file to edit a remote file locally.  (See http://is.gd/9dwq for dependencies.)
/fred|joe/ will search for either fred OR joe.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/.*fred&.*joe/ will search for fred AND joe, in any order.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/< fred  >/ will search for fred, but not alfred or frederick.  http://is.gd/4xZW (spaces inserted to avoid HTML filtering).
/joe/e will search for joe and place the cursor at the end of the match. http://is.gd/4xZW
/joe/e+1 will search for joe and place the cursor at the end of the match, plus on character.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/joe/s-2 will search for joe and place the cursor at the start of the match, minus two characters.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/joe/+3 will search for joe and place the cursor three lines below the match.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/joe.*fred.*bill/ will search for joe AND fred AND bill, in that order.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/begin\_.*end will search for begin AND end over multiple lines.  http://is.gd/4xZW
/fred\_s*joe/ will search for fred AND joe with whitespace (including newline) in between.  http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s//joe/igc substitute your last search with joe. http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/~/sue/igc substitute your last replacement string with sue. http://is.gd/4xZW
2f/ would find the second occurrence of '/' in a line.  http://is.gd/cCHy
Basic commands 'f' and 't' (like first and 'til) are very powerful.  See :help t or :help f.  http://is.gd/cCHy
:40,50m30 will move lines 40 through 50 to line 30. Most visual mode commands can be used w/ line numbers.  http://is.gd/cCHy
To search for a URL without backslashing, search backwards!  Example: ?http://somestuff.com  http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/~/sue/igc substitute your last replacement string with 'sue'.  http://is.gd/4xZW
g; will cycle through your recent changes (or g, to go in reverse.  http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/^ \ n \{3}// will delete a block of 3 empty lines. (remove the spaces) http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/^\ n\ +/\ r/  will compress multiple empty lines into one.  (remove spaces) http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s#<[^>]\+>##g will remove HTML tags, leaving the text. (non-greedy) http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s#.*(hours).*#1# will delete everything on a line except for the string 'hours'.  http://is.gd/4xZW
:s/\(.*\):\(.*\)/\2 : \1/ will reverse fields separated by ':'  http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/joe|fred/jerks/g will replace both 'fred' and 'joe' with 'jerks'. http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/< ! - -\_.\{-}-- >// will delete HTML comments, potentially spanning multiple lines. (remove the spaces) http://is.gd/4xZW
:g/search_term/# display each line containing 'search_term' with line numbers. http://is.gd/4xZW
% matches brackets {} [] (), and with matchit.vim, also matches def/end, < ?php/?>, < p>/< /p>, etc.  http://is.gd/N4W
:Sex will open a file explorer in a split window.  I bet you'll remember that one.  http://is.gd/4xZW
:lcd %:p:h will change to the directory of the current file. http://is.gd/4xZW
ggguG will lower case the entire file (also known as the Jerry Yang treatment).  http://is.gd/4xZW
:r !date will insert the current date/time stamp (from the 'date' command -- a bit OS-specific).   http://is.gd/4xZW
:%s/[.!?]\_s\+\a/\U&\E/g will uppercase the first letter of each sentence (except the very first one). http://is.gd/4xZW
ga will display the ASCII, hex, and octal value of the character under the cursor. http://is.gd/4xZW
gf will open the file under the cursor.  (Killer feature.) http://is.gd/4xZW
Ctrl-a, Ctrl-x will increment and decrement, respectively, the number under the cursor. http://is.gd/4xZW
:tab sball will re-tab all files in the buffers list. http://is.gd/4xZW
; is a motion to repeat last find with f. f' would find next quote. c; would change up to the next ' (via @techpickles) http://is.gd/qZIs
Use '\v' in your regex to set the mode to 'very magic', and avoid confusion. (:h \v for more info.) http://is.gd/tj4y
Ctrl-c to quickly get out of command-line mode.  (Faster than hitting ESC a couple times.)  http://is.gd/GTtq
:%s/\ v(.*\ n){5}/&\ r will insert a blank line every 5 lines (remove spaces) http://is.gd/6PB6n
qa starts a recording in register 'a'. q stops it. @a repeats the recording. 5@a repeats it 5 times.  http://is.gd/6PB6n
:vsplit filename will split the window vertically and open the file in the left-hand pane.  Great when writing unit tests!
:tabdo [some command] will execute the command in all tabs.  Also see windo, bufdo, argdo.
:scriptnames will list all plugins and _vimrcs loaded. http://is.gd/6PB6n
:set guifont=* in gvim or MacVim to get a font selection dialog. Useful while giving presentations. (via @claytron)
ci " inside a " " will erase everything between "" and place you in insertion mode. (via @rbernardelli)

to use gvim to edit your git messages set git's core editor as follows:
git config --global core.editor "gvim --nofork" (via @EmmanuelOga)
:read [filename] will insert the contents of [filename] at the current cursor position (via @claytron)
:set autochdir instead of :lcd %:p:h in your vimrc to change directories upon opening a file. (via @jmdeldin)
ci{ – change text inside {} block. Also see di{, yi{, ci( etc. http://is.gd/cT0dc
You probably know that 'u' is undo. Do you know that Ctrl-R is redo?
After performing an undo, you can navigate through the changes using g- and g+. Also, try :undolist to list the changes. http://is.gd/cT0dc
:wa will save all buffers. :xa will save all buffers and exit Vim. http://is.gd/do1qZ
"2p will put the second to last thing yanked, "3p will put the third to last, etc. http://is.gd/do1Dt
"_d will delete the selection without adding it to the yanked stack (sending it to the black hole register). http://is.gd/do1Dt
In insert mode do Ctrl+r=53+17<Enter>. This way you can do some calcs with vim. (via @grasselli)
[I (that's bracket-open, capital-i) shows lines containing the word under the cursor (via @nvie)
'0 opens the last modified file ('1 '2 '3 works too) (via @grasselli)
ggVG= will auto-format the entire document

Edit a command output in Vim as a file:
$ command | vim - (via @dlibanori)
%s/<C-R>a/bar/g will place the contents of register 'a' in the search, and replace it with 'bar'.

:vimgrep /stext/ **/*.txt | :copen
searches for stext recursively in *.txt files and show results in separate window (via @danechkin)
In visual mode, use s" to surround the selected text with " using the surround plugin. http://is.gd/fpwJQ (via @grasselli)
ysiw' to surround current word with ', cs'{ changes 'word' to { word } using the surround plugin http://is.gd/fpwJQ (via @oriolgual)
Edit and encrypt a file: vim -x filename (via @dlibanori)
K runs a prgrm to lookup the keyword under the cursor. If writing C, it runs man. In Ruby, it (should) run ri, Python (perhaps) pydoc.
:w !sudo tee % will use sudo to write the open file (have you ever forgotten to `sudo vim /path/to/file`?)  (via @gbretou)
CTRL-w K will switch vertical split into horizontal, CTRL-w H will switch a horizontal into a vertical. (via @mpetrsson)
CTRL-w s CTRL-w T will open current buffer in new tab (via @vrybas_)
vim -c [command] will launch vim and run a : command at launch, e.g. "vim -c NERDTree." (via @sgharms)
:g/_pattern_/s/^/#/g will comment out lines containing _pattern_ (if '#' is your comment character/sequence) (via @vrybas_)
%s/^ \ n/ / to delete all empty lines (remove spaces from command!) (via @marekkubis)
CTRL-w | and CTRL-W _ maximize your current split vertically and horizontally, respectively. CTRL-W = equalizes 'em.
zz to center the cursor vertically on your screen. Useful when you 250Gzz, for instance. http://is.gd/XKGK1X

:%s/\\/\//g
Replaces all backslashes with forward slashes.
Use "_dd to delete one line without overriding the buffer. "_ is black hole register. "When writing to this register, nothing happens."
In your ~/.vimrc, `set clipboard=unnamed`. Now all operations work with the OS clipboard. No need for "+, "* (via @panozzaj)
